description:
Wife cake is a Cantonese [bakery item](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Chinese_bakery_products). Also known as [sweetheart cake](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweetheart_cake), it's a round flaky pastry filled with a wintermelon paste.

**Origins**

There are several stories explaining the name of this pastry, for example an ailing man named it after his wife who sold herself into slavery to pay for his doctor (apparently they didn't have Medicare for All), or less dramatically, a man like this pastry his wife made so much that he named it after her.

**Characters**

{老婆} is *wife* ({老} is *old*, and {婆} is *lady*, so it's just like the American use of *old lady* to mean *wife*). {餅} is *cookie* or *pastry*.

A pastry filled with [lotus seed paste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_seed_paste).

**Characters**

{蓮蓉} is [lotus seed paste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_seed_paste) ({蓮} is *lotus*, and {蓉} is *paste*). {餅} is *cookie* or *pastry*.

description:
These almond-flavored crumbly cookies were introduced by early Chinese-American immigrants but are now popular worldwide and can be found in Chinatowns, Chinese bakeries and restaurants. There is typically an almond in the center of the cookie that is supposed to bring good luck.

**Characters**

{杏仁} is *almond*, and {餅} is *cookie*, so {杏仁餅} is *almond cookie*.

[Fortune cookies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_cookie) are ubiquitious in Chinese-American restaurants and can be found in bakeries and grocery stores (but I've never seen one in Hong Kong).

**History**

There's debate whether fortune cookies are of Chinese-American or Japanese-American origin, and whether they originated in San Francisco or Los Angeles, but either way, it could be claimed they derive from Japan in the form of [tsujiura senbei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsujiura), notes baked into crackers.

**Characters**

{簽} is a slip of paper, {語} generally means *to say* but in this case specifically is *proverb*, and {餅} is *cookie*. So 簽語餅 is *paper proverb cookie*.

Western-style cookies. If you go into a Chinese supermarket, the cookie section will include tins of Chinese biscuits but also tins of European cookies.

**Characters**

{曲奇} is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) from the English *cookie* (which is derived from the Dutch *koekje*, which is *little cake*). In particular, the Cantonese pronunciation *kūk kèih* sounds like *cookie*.

The Chinese for Chinese cookie-like things is {餅}, so sometimes Western cookies are termed 曲奇餅 (kūk kèih béng in Cantonese) which would translate to *cookie cookie*.
